personal.name: Ayush Ghosh
personal.title: AI Product Manager & Engineer
personal.subtitle: AI PM | Advanced Analytics
personal.description: AI product leader with 5+ years delivering production AI and analytics products. I define roadmaps, prioritize ML features with stakeholders, and coordinate engineering, data, and design teams to ship measurable outcomes. Technical fluency includes Python, LangChain, TensorFlow, AWS, and MLOps.

description: 0→1 Product Strategy: Spearheading the product vision and roadmap for an AI-driven visual diagnostic platform; translating clinical research into a scalable MVP to standardize global dermatology workflows.

Market Validation & Growth: Leading end-to-end customer discovery and success for early enterprise partners, defining the core product-market fit and instrumentation metrics that drive a category-defining health-tech platform.
AI Strategy & Delivery: Spearheaded the roadmap for a RAG-based executive intelligence tool, reducing analyst prep time by 25% through automated synthesis of complex financial data.

Operational Transformation: Modernized data infrastructure using Databricks to accelerate model iteration by 30%, while deploying interactive BI dashboards that shortened executive decision cycles by 20%.
Product Lifecycle Management: Led the telemetry sync roadmap to achieve 99% uptime and launched a centralized clinical dashboard that slashed support resolution time (MTTR) by 40%.
Cross-Functional Leadership: Optimized the patient journey analytics pipeline by 50% while leading Agile ceremonies that improved team sprint velocity by 20%.
Optimized implant-telemetry flow—cut sync delay 30% and achieved 99% uptime by writing the C# ingestion code, SQLite caching and AWS ETL.
Built a log-manager dashboard (S3 events & DynamoDB) that improved remote debugging throughput by 40%.
Data-Driven Growth: Developed KPI frameworks and physician engagement models for the Ozempic program, resulting in a 30% increase in engagement and measurable market share uplift.
Scalable Insights: Engineered real-time analytics dashboards processing 10M+ records monthly, accelerating the insight-to-action cycle for global commercial teams.
Managed a 150+ member team at the Entrepreneurship Development Cell, mentoring startups and securing $190K in funding.
Led digital content strategy and market research at CoLinkers Event Management, boosting event visibility and engagement by 20%.
Analyzed SCADA and DCS data, collaborated with the Control and Instrumentation department, achieved 15% downtime reduction through data-driven optimization of equipment and processes.

Analyzed data produced by Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems to discover trends, patterns, and anomalies in temperature, pressure, and other important indicators in a power generating unit for an aluminum and copper manufacturing facility.

Contributed to international supply chain operations by supporting the relationships with suppliers across 18 countries. Assisted in the development and implementation of a supplier scorecard that reduced defects by 3%.

Combined data analysis and content marketing expertise to optimize digital content strategy for website, social media, and email newsletters. Conducted market research and used SEO techniques to increase online visibility and contributed to successful event outcomes.

degrees.degree: Bachelor in Engineering of Electronics & Communications

certifications.title: Certified Six Sigma Green Belt
certifications.issuer: Minnesota West Community and Technical College

projects.title: Mobile App UI/UX
projects.description: Designed 15+ Figma/Balsamiq Mobile app screens based on user research; validated UX through stakeholder walkthroughs, reducing rework by 30%.

projects.title: Academic World Dashboard
projects.description: Designed and deployed full-stack Dash dashboard, handling 100k+ daily requests with containerized microservices. Implemented advanced graph queries in Neo4j to uncover research collaborations, increasing stakeholder insight by 60%.

projects.title: Personalised Loyalty Model
projects.description: Developed and tuned the XGBoost recommendation engine, achieving 98.8% accuracy on customer retention predictions. Visualized model output with interactive dashboards in Tableau to guide marketing strategy, increasing campaign ROI by 25%.

projects.title: AI Resume Generator
projects.description: Built a RAG pipeline using LangChain and FAISS for vector similarity search, achieving 92% relevance on test queries. Implemented GPT-4 integration to generate ATS-optimized resumes and cover letters from job descriptions, reducing manual drafting time by 80%.

caseStudies.title: Team Promotion & Talent Scaling as a Product Problem
caseStudies.summary: Built a repeatable promotion and talent-scaling system to reduce attrition risk while increasing delivery capacity.
caseStudies.metric: Lower attrition risk and improved delivery predictability via structured promotion and capacity planning.
caseStudies.problem: As teams scaled, promotion decisions were inconsistent and capacity bottlenecks increased attrition and knowledge-loss risk.
strategy: Framed org design as a product system with inputs, constraints, and measurable outcomes.
Created structured promotion cases combining business need, readiness, and role scope.
Connected capacity planning to product roadmap risk.
execution: Standardized promotion packets and review criteria across teams.
Mapped critical knowledge nodes and succession coverage for high-risk functions.
Used quarterly capacity reviews to rebalance hiring, promotion, and role design.
outcome: Reduced attrition and protected continuity on high-priority initiatives.
Improved promotion transparency and manager alignment.
Increased delivery predictability by aligning people plans with roadmap demand.
caseStudies.tradeoffs: Chose rigor and consistency over speed in promotion cycles to avoid short-term morale spikes and long-term capability gaps.
caseStudies.nextStep: Add leading indicators for burnout and skill-gap risk to improve forecast accuracy.
decisionOptions: Fast-track promotions ad hoc to close immediate gaps quickly.
Freeze promotions until organization structure stabilizes.
Use a structured promotion rubric tied to business need and role readiness.
caseStudies.decisionChosen: Used a structured promotion rubric tied to business need and role readiness.
caseStudies.decisionWhy: This balanced short-term execution speed with long-term capability quality, while reducing fairness and attrition risks from inconsistent decisions.
caseStudies.whatIdDoDifferently: Run calibration workshops one cycle earlier and publish example scorecards sooner to improve manager consistency in the first rollout.

caseStudies.title: Tesla Model Y Battery Warranty ROI Analysis
caseStudies.summary: Modeled warranty cost vs failure probability to estimate expected consumer value for high-mileage ownership.
caseStudies.metric: Break-even and expected-value thresholds by usage profile (including 110k+ mile scenarios).
caseStudies.problem: Consumers lacked a clear framework to decide whether extended battery warranty pricing was economically rational past 110k miles.
strategy: Defined decision model using warranty price, claim payout range, and failure likelihood.
Segmented scenarios by usage intensity and mileage trajectory.
Compared expected value against downside-risk protection.
execution: Built scenario-based ROI model with base, optimistic, and stress assumptions.
Tested outcomes for 110k+ mile usage patterns and time-to-failure windows.
Translated analysis into a simple decision-support recommendation for non-technical buyers.
outcome: Quantified break-even thresholds for warranty value by usage profile.
Clarified when risk protection justified price premium versus self-insurance.
Created reusable framework relevant to Consumer PM, FinTech, and Insurance PM contexts.
caseStudies.tradeoffs: Kept the model interpretable and scenario-driven instead of overfitting assumptions with limited field-failure data.
caseStudies.nextStep: Extend the model with real-world claim datasets and dynamic pricing sensitivity.
decisionOptions: Use anecdotal owner experiences as the primary decision basis.
Build a complex probabilistic model with many hidden assumptions.
Use a transparent scenario-based expected-value model segmented by mileage profile.
caseStudies.decisionChosen: Built a transparent scenario-based expected-value model segmented by mileage profile.
caseStudies.decisionWhy: Interpretability was critical for consumer trust, and scenario modeling handled uncertainty without sacrificing actionability.
caseStudies.whatIdDoDifferently: Incorporate real claims datasets and resale value sensitivity to tighten confidence intervals and improve external validity.

caseStudies.title: Sculptor Capital: Operational Efficiency & Internal Tools
caseStudies.summary: Improved analyst workflow throughput by building internal tooling that reduced prep time by 25%.
caseStudies.metric: 25% reduction in analyst preparation time and measurable internal cost savings.
caseStudies.problem: Analysts were spending disproportionate time on manual prep tasks, creating bottlenecks in high-stakes decision workflows.
strategy: Approached internal tooling as a product with clear user jobs and adoption constraints.
Prioritized bottlenecks with highest time-cost and downstream business impact.
Aligned stakeholders on workflow fit, reliability, and rollout sequencing.
execution: Led discovery with analysts and business leads to map friction points.
Shipped workflow-integrated features that minimized context switching.
Instrumented usage and cycle-time metrics to drive iterative improvements.
outcome: Reduced analyst preparation time by 25%.
Lowered manual operational load and improved effective team capacity.
Delivered measurable cost savings through workflow optimization.
caseStudies.tradeoffs: Scoped narrowly to high-frequency pain points first rather than broad platform redesign.
caseStudies.nextStep: Expand automation coverage into adjacent workflows while preserving trust and auditability.
decisionOptions: Rebuild the full internal workflow platform end-to-end.
Ship isolated scripts for each team without common instrumentation.
Prioritize targeted tools for the highest-frequency bottlenecks inside existing workflows.
caseStudies.decisionChosen: Prioritized targeted tools for highest-frequency bottlenecks inside existing workflows.
caseStudies.decisionWhy: This gave the fastest measurable throughput gains with lower adoption risk in a high-stakes operating environment.
caseStudies.whatIdDoDifferently: Introduce shared event instrumentation from day one to quantify secondary effects across adjacent analyst workflows.

caseStudies.title: SOCAi Labs: AI Vision for Medical Diagnostics
caseStudies.summary: Built a 0-to-1 AI diagnostics product path centered on PMF, clinical trust, and measurable diagnostic efficiency.
caseStudies.metric: Improved diagnostic workflow speed and consistency in pilot settings versus manual-only checks.
caseStudies.problem: Dermatology workflows faced slow triage and inconsistent classification quality across geographies and specialist availability.
strategy: Focused PMF on alopecia-specific AI vision use cases with clear clinical value.
Balanced model accuracy targets with real-time processing requirements.
Designed for dual user needs across clinicians and patients.
execution: Ran discovery across clinical stakeholders to shape MVP scope and adoption flow.
Defined evaluation metrics for classification quality, time-to-diagnosis, and usability.
Coordinated engineering and data roadmaps for safe iteration in a MedTech context.
outcome: Established a validated 0-to-1 product direction for AI-assisted hair-loss diagnostics.
Improved diagnostic workflow speed and consistency versus manual-only checks in pilot settings.
Created a scalable roadmap for clinical deployment and product expansion.
caseStudies.tradeoffs: Deferred lower-impact features to prioritize model reliability and clinician trust in early releases.
caseStudies.nextStep: Scale across additional diagnostic categories while tightening monitoring and governance.
decisionOptions: Launch broad dermatology coverage from day one.
Focus only on model research before productizing workflows.
Start with a narrow alopecia-focused MVP and clinician-in-the-loop workflow.
caseStudies.decisionChosen: Started with a narrow alopecia-focused MVP and clinician-in-the-loop workflow.
caseStudies.decisionWhy: Narrowing scope improved product-market fit signal quality and reduced clinical adoption and governance risk in early stages.
caseStudies.whatIdDoDifferently: Run payer and clinical integration discovery in parallel earlier to reduce downstream go-to-market and deployment delays.

caseStudies.title: Organizational Design: The Founding PM
caseStudies.summary: Designed the team architecture for a resource-constrained startup by treating organization design as a product scalability problem.
caseStudies.metric: Closed MLOps and data-engineering capability gaps tied directly to delivery scalability risk.
caseStudies.problem: Early-stage execution risk increased because generalist-heavy staffing left critical gaps in MLOps and data engineering.
strategy: Defined the operating model as the machine that builds the product machine.
Prioritized role coverage based on technical scalability risk, not headcount convenience.
Mapped hiring sequence to roadmap dependencies and failure modes.
execution: Audited current team capabilities against near-term product milestones.
Built role scorecards to justify MLOps and Data Engineering hires over generic generalists.
Aligned founders and functional leads on phased org design decisions.
outcome: Closed critical talent gaps threatening product reliability and scale.
Improved delivery resilience for end-to-end AI product execution.
Created clearer ownership boundaries across product, data, and platform work.
caseStudies.tradeoffs: Accepted slower broad hiring in exchange for high-leverage specialist roles tied to product risk.
caseStudies.nextStep: Institutionalize capability reviews each quarter to keep org design aligned with roadmap evolution.
decisionOptions: Scale quickly with mostly generalist hiring.
Outsource critical platform and data functions temporarily.
Prioritize targeted MLOps and data-engineering roles tied to roadmap risk.
caseStudies.decisionChosen: Prioritized targeted MLOps and data-engineering roles tied directly to roadmap risk.
caseStudies.decisionWhy: Specialist ownership reduced execution fragility and protected scaling-critical capabilities that generalist staffing could not sustain.
caseStudies.whatIdDoDifferently: Establish a formal capability matrix and succession risk review in quarter one instead of after initial hiring.

caseStudies.title: The Data Bottleneck: Active Learning & Hard Example Mining
caseStudies.summary: Reframed dataset growth from labeling everything to labeling the most informative samples for faster model improvement.
caseStudies.metric: Higher model performance gain per labeled sample with reduced annotation burn rate.
caseStudies.problem: Alopecia capture volume was high, but most images were unlabeled and manual annotation of the full corpus was too slow and expensive.
strategy: Moved from big-data mindset to smart-data prioritization.
Designed an active-learning loop that surfaced low-confidence and edge-case images first.
Linked labeling priorities directly to model error patterns and product risk.
execution: Implemented confidence-based triage to route hard examples for human review.
Built annotation queues optimized for expected model lift, not raw volume.
Set batch-level evaluation checkpoints to validate accuracy gains per annotation cycle.
outcome: Improved model learning efficiency by prioritizing high-information samples.
Reduced annotation burn without compromising quality progression.
Created a repeatable data-ops workflow for faster iteration.
caseStudies.tradeoffs: Accepted reduced broad-label coverage in exchange for higher marginal learning value per labeled image.
caseStudies.nextStep: Add active-learning policies by clinical subtype to further improve precision and fairness.
decisionOptions: Label the entire dataset uniformly over time.
Label random batches to spread effort evenly.
Use active learning to prioritize low-confidence and hard-example samples.
caseStudies.decisionChosen: Used active learning to prioritize low-confidence and hard-example samples.
caseStudies.decisionWhy: This maximized model performance lift per annotation dollar and accelerated learning cycles under constrained labeling capacity.
caseStudies.whatIdDoDifferently: Add labeler calibration and inter-rater quality checks earlier to further improve consistency on ambiguous examples.

caseStudies.title: Infrastructure Design: Separating Feature APIs from Model Pipelines
caseStudies.summary: Avoided the AI monolith trap by splitting consumer-facing APIs from heavy model/data pipeline workloads.
caseStudies.metric: Increased product and research throughput by decoupling API workloads from ML pipeline operations.
caseStudies.problem: Combining app-facing backend responsibilities with ML training pipelines created scaling bottlenecks and slowed both product delivery and research velocity.
strategy: Separated architecture ownership between feature APIs and MLOps/data pipelines.
Defined interface contracts to decouple product iteration from model training jobs.
Aligned team structure to support multiple AI researchers without infra collapse.
execution: Partitioned service boundaries and ownership by workload pattern.
Introduced dedicated MLOps/data engineering capacity for training and deployment reliability.
Established SLA and observability standards for both real-time APIs and batch pipelines.
outcome: Reduced infrastructure contention between user features and model operations.
Improved delivery throughput for product and research teams in parallel.
Lowered technical debt risk from monolithic coupling.
caseStudies.tradeoffs: Took on short-term coordination overhead to gain long-term scalability and fault isolation.
caseStudies.nextStep: Automate contract testing and deployment gates across API and model-serving boundaries.
decisionOptions: Keep one backend monolith for feature APIs and ML pipelines.
Split code paths but keep undifferentiated shared ownership.
Separate architecture and ownership for feature APIs versus model/data pipelines.
caseStudies.decisionChosen: Separated architecture and ownership for feature APIs versus model/data pipelines.
caseStudies.decisionWhy: Workload isolation improved reliability and let product delivery and ML iteration progress in parallel without mutual contention.
caseStudies.whatIdDoDifferently: Define service contracts and SLO boundaries before the split to reduce coordination overhead during migration.

caseStudies.title: Algorithm-Hardware Co-Design: VLSI + AI in Healthcare
caseStudies.summary: Explored co-design approaches to run medical-grade AI with lower power and latency constraints on edge-capable hardware.
caseStudies.metric: Defined feasibility envelope for lower-power edge inference while preserving clinically meaningful confidence.
caseStudies.problem: High-fidelity diagnostic models are computationally expensive and difficult to deploy in environments without large cloud GPU capacity.
strategy: Investigated approximate-computing and co-design techniques for cost-efficient inference.
Framed precision-performance tradeoffs around clinical safety thresholds.
Positioned hardware-aware modeling as a product strategy for edge deployment access.
execution: Mapped candidate model components for precision relaxation with bounded error budgets.
Evaluated power, latency, and throughput impacts against target use environments.
Translated engineering constraints into product requirements and rollout scenarios.
outcome: Established a path for power-efficient AI deployment beyond cloud-only architectures.
Clarified product feasibility boundaries for low-infrastructure markets.
Created a decision framework balancing clinical confidence with hardware constraints.
caseStudies.tradeoffs: Accepted minor precision tolerance in controlled components to unlock major efficiency gains.
caseStudies.nextStep: Prototype clinical validation workflows for edge inference configurations under real operating conditions.
decisionOptions: Depend on cloud-only inference for all diagnostic workloads.
Apply aggressive precision reduction across all model components.
Use targeted co-design with bounded precision relaxation in selected components.
caseStudies.decisionChosen: Used targeted co-design with bounded precision relaxation in selected components.
caseStudies.decisionWhy: This preserved clinically meaningful confidence while unlocking practical power and latency improvements for edge deployment.
caseStudies.whatIdDoDifferently: Prototype on representative hardware platforms earlier to validate theoretical gains against real deployment constraints.

caseStudies.title: Moving from 2D to 3D: Spatial Capture Research
caseStudies.summary: Designed a research roadmap for spatial capture to improve data fidelity while balancing user capture friction.
caseStudies.metric: Created decision thresholds for when 3D capture accuracy gains justify additional user effort.
caseStudies.problem: 2D scalp photos lacked depth, scale, and lighting consistency, producing noisy inputs and unstable model predictions.
strategy: Evaluated spatial/3D capture approaches for clinically useful data quality gains.
Defined product requirements around accuracy lift versus capture effort.
Positioned user-friction constraints as first-class roadmap inputs.
execution: Compared candidate pipelines using depth sensing and photogrammetry concepts.
Specified quality metrics for geometric consistency and downstream model impact.
Designed staged UX experiments to test capture completion and usability.
outcome: Improved clarity on when 3D capture materially improves prediction reliability.
Created decision criteria for introducing advanced capture only where value exceeds friction.
Provided a roadmap to move toward clinical-grade capture with controlled UX complexity.
caseStudies.tradeoffs: Avoided immediate full 3D rollout to prevent user drop-off while validating quality benefits first.
caseStudies.nextStep: Pilot hybrid capture flows that dynamically escalate from 2D to 3D for ambiguous cases.
decisionOptions: Remain fully 2D to keep capture friction minimal.
Move all users to mandatory 3D capture immediately.
Adopt a hybrid flow that escalates from 2D to 3D for ambiguous cases.
caseStudies.decisionChosen: Adopted a hybrid flow that escalates from 2D to 3D for ambiguous cases.
caseStudies.decisionWhy: Hybrid capture balanced data-fidelity gains against user friction and protected completion rates while improving accuracy where it mattered most.
caseStudies.whatIdDoDifferently: Pilot guided capture prompts and real-time quality feedback earlier to reduce user drop-off in advanced capture steps.

testimonials.quote: Ayush is a super smart guy with keen intuition. Very strong on both technical and soft skills. Good at his job, good at communicating, good at reasoning and seeing underlying patterns and importance.

testimonials.title: Sr. Firmware Engineer

testimonials.quote: Ayush is the kind of engineer everyone wants to work with: He's inquisitive and quick to learn new material and concepts; he's passionate about the medical device industry service to our patients; he's innovative and knowledgeable about his field and beyond; he's a good teacher -- I learned a lot from him; and he's very personable, even under pressure. Ayush has a shining career ahead of him.
testimonials.name: John Osmand
testimonials.title: Embedded Software and Signal Processing Engineer

testimonials.quote: I'm happy to recommend Ayush Ghosh, a talented engineer in our R&D department. He enhanced our clinical mobile app by merging diverse datasets, creating custom visualizations, and delivering data-science insights that shaped our development decisions. Ayush is skilled in cloud APIs, Python-driven workflows, and dashboard design, communicates clearly, and consistently supports his teammates.

testimonials.title: Senior Principal Software Engineer

testimonials.quote: I had the privilege of studying alongside Ayush during our Master's in Engineering Management, and I can confidently say that his analytical prowess and leadership abilities are truly exceptional. Ayush consistently demonstrated a keen insight into complex problems and a proactive approach to collaborative learning. His ability to balance rigorous academic demands with innovative thinking made him an invaluable teammate.

testimonials.title: Field Engineer

testimonials.quote: My overlap with Ayush was just a couple of months, however, during that time what I have noticed is that Ayush has a great analytical thought process and he is always ready to take up new challenges. His curiosity to learn new things and evolve is something that helps him in doing that as well. Based on what I have seen and heard, he is going to excel wherever he goes.

testimonials.title: Manager

testimonials.quote: Ayush has shown immense competitiveness and analytical skills in his tenure of 1.5 years at ZS. He has good work ethics and a learning attitude which will help him take his career to a height.

testimonials.title: Data Science and Analytics Professional

testimonials.quote: Having worked with many professionals throughout my journey, Ayush was a unique one to work with. He has critical thinking ability and always ready to take up challenges and explore new avenues. His work ethics are pristine and his ability to tackle any problem is remarkable with a warm smile. Ayush would become appreciated member of any team.

testimonials.quote: I've worked with Ayush since he joined ZS, and it has been a pleasure to watch him grow as a team member. He has shown great coordination with other team members and was always flexible to take up the different tasks. Ayush's strength is his command of complex data analytics, allowing him to undertake large projects easily. He has also drawn insightful summaries which helped the team to take important decisions.

testimonials.quote: I worked with Ayush on a Final-Year entrepreneurship project, his dedication towards work is unmatched and he thrives under pressure. He is dependable and efficient in carrying out the tasks in hand.

testimonials.title: Strategy Consultant

testimonials.quote: Ayush is a very hard-working individual and a great team player. He is a quick learner and knows the correct way to implement his learning. He has a very positive aura which motivates the complete team.

testimonials.title: R&D HVDC Engineer

testimonials.quote: Ayush is a motivated, forward-thinking and intelligent person who has lots of knowledge in his field. It was wonderful to work with him. He leads by example and I find his enthusiasm and dedication both inspiring and motivating.

testimonials.title: Product Manager

testimonials.quote: Ayush is an eager learner with a sharp mind. He has displayed enhanced resourcefulness in all his engagements. I had the opportunity to mentor him for communication skills and he excelled in the programme through his innovative and creative participation. Ayush's organisational skills and interpersonal relationship skills were pleasantly displayed during an event he had managed for his university.
